metadata.title: Calcific Tendinitis of the Shoulder
synonyms: rotator cuff calcific tendinitis,calcifying tendinitis, shoulder
anatomical location body part affected: Shoulder joint/rotator cuff tendons, rarely involving the tendon of long head of the biceps; subacromial space (coracoacromial arch)(1)
description: Calcific tendinitis of the shoulder (CT) is a condition associated with crystal calcium hydroxyapatite deposition in one or more of the rotator cuff tendons.(1) The calcifications likely disturb normal shoulder joint mobility. Physical functioning of the affected shoulder is typically limited by activity-related  pain(29)

Patients may present in acute, subacute, or chronic stages of CT. Most acute cases resolve spontaneously. In chronic stages, the supraspinatus tendon is usually involved, and late-developing  sequelae often include subacromial impingement(2)

Uhthoff's classification includes a pre-calcific  stage in which tenocytes undergo metaplasia to chondrocytes, followed by a calcific stage, and post-calcific  phase. The calcific phase is further delineated into formative, resting, and resorptive phases(35). Pain is reported worst during the resorptive phase

The initial management approach is usually conservative, which involves therapeutic modalities for pain management and exercises for restoring deficits in shoulder flexibility and strength,(2,3,4,5) as well as shoulder mechanics and scapular stability. Oral nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory  drugs (NSAIDs) are commonly prescribed

Extracorporeal shock wave therapy (ESWT) and ultrasound-guided  needling (UGN) are other management options. Arthroscopic debridement or decompression surgery may be necessary when the calcifications are large or pain persists after conservative treatment(3,29,30,38)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement have been identified for calcific tendinitis of the shoulder. Reimbursement will depend on individual insurance coverage
presentation signs and symptoms: Patients are often 40 to 50 years of age(1)
Presentation is typically after recent (less than 1 month) sudden onset of activity-related  shoulder symptoms
Patients with chronic CT complain of constant ache and exquisite tenderness at anterolateral shoulder
Pain-restricted  shoulder range of motion (ROM) with limitations in activities of daily living (ADLs)
Active guarding/splinting of arm to lessen pain
Bilateral shoulder symptoms are not uncommon Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

causes: Etiology of CT is unknown in nontraumatic cases. Several theories have been proposed(9,10,30)

Repetitive overuse or acute trauma may not be etiologic factors because acute calcifying supraspinatus tendinitis can occurwithout tendon damage or degenerative changes, as was confirmed in a 3-year-old  child who recovered spontaneously(6)
CT is not a primary shoulder impingement syndrome,(7) although it may progress to subacromial impingement and rotatorcuff tear in adults(2,3,8)
pathogenesis: The crystals in the tendons of patients with CT are composed of calcium hydroxyapatite. This is an inorganic material madeup of calcium phosphate, calcium carbonate, calcium fluoride, and calcium hydroxide
There are a number of classifications of CT, which involve different morphologic features found on radiographs(31)
CT is a variant inflammatory condition with an atypical immune response(1,2,36,37)
The pathogenic mechanism of CT is unclear. One theory proposesthat localized hypovascularitymay trigger calcification(9)

Incomplete endochondral calcification creates a fibrocartilage-like  tendon; this is followed by an infiltration ofphagocytosing cells, formation of new vascular channels, and calcium resorption that self-limits  the condition(9,10)

The calcific material producesa vigorous inflammatory response, as indicated by increased accumulation of mast cellsand macrophages. This phase is followed by neovascularization and neoinnervation in the lesions that are associated withincreased pain during the resorptive phase(36)
Pain and restriction of movement are worst in the resorptive phase because the calcium crystals extravasate into thesubacromial bursa(11)

A current theory is that weakening of the muscle-tendon  complex leads tothe formation of tenocytes. These new tenocytesdifferentiate into hypertrophic chondrocyte-like  cells that produce tissue-nonspecific  alkaline phosphatase, which promotesthe calcium deposits(37)
Although corticosteroid injection may reduce pain in some phases, it mayinterfere with the cell-mediated  resorption ofcalciumin other cases(10)
Common complications of CT include:(12,31)–subacromial impingement(7)–rotator cuff tear(8,15)–adhesive capsulitis(13)–greater tuberosity osteolysis–ossifying tendinitis
risk factors ,,: Systemic conditions associated with calcification, including gouty arthritis, various rheumatic diseases, and hypercalcemiaof any cause
Clinical associations with diabetes and thyroid disorders have been reported

overall contraindications precautions: Cases that should be referred back to physician Suspected fracture Suspected rotator cuff tear Catching and pseudo-locking:  this presentation is atypical, suggestive of loose bodies in subacromial space
Patients who present after traumatic shoulder injury are at high risk for developing glenohumeral adhesive capsulitis(1,2)
Consider imaging studies and invasive options for recalcitrant cases, as indicated by persistent pain after 2-3 months of conservative treatment and activity modification(2,13,14)
Avoid activities that may exacerbate condition, especially overhead activities
See specific  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan of Care

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Document date of onset. Idiopathic in most cases and no specific trauma or overuse cause is identified. If trauma was involved,have the symptoms changed?  -Typically, abrupt onset of symptoms -First symptom may occur during overhead shoulder activities -Symptoms can intensify over a short time, suggesting that the condition is acute or subacute

course of treatment.medical management: Document the management the patient has received for this condition and what has been helpful. Conservative treatments have been reported effective in many studies.(14)Has ESWT been tried?(15)
surgical management: Document any invasive procedures to remove or promote calcium resorption
Minimally-invasive  procedures and surgical options include the following:(13,14,29,30)
Subacromial infiltration with corticosteroids or anesthetics
course of treatment.medications: NSAIDs and other analgesic medications (e.g., tramadol) are commonly prescribed. Are they being taken and are they effectively controlling the patient’s symptoms?
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  The diagnosis is confirmed by standard radiographs and ultrasonographic evidence of clearly circumscribed and dense calcification only in the affected tendon(s)(11)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Patient may actively guard/splint arm to lessen pain. Overhead activities are painful (e.g., dusting high shelves)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms. Bilateral symptoms are not uncommon
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of pain (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). Does pain provoke guarding or splinting of the arm? Patients commonly report a constant ache, exquisite tenderness at shoulder, and/or shoulder stiffness. In general, are patient’s symptoms better, worse, or the same?
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 0-10 scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if  pain  is present now and how much ). Pain may be intense
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night, if any. Night pain is not uncommon.(14) Pain can also occur when lying on affected shoulder. Is the patient able to reduce pain by using pillows to position the arm or elevate the upper body?
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe ________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Any prior history of shoulder problems? Any history of gouty arthritis or rheumatic diseases?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, thyroid disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, orthopedic disorders, etc.
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter  drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing. Is the patient an active smoker, or attempting to quit smoking? Social/occupational historyWhat are the patient’s goals for therapy? Does the patient participate in sports? Does the condition interfere with patient’s ability to perform occupational duties?Does the patient require assistance with dressing or other personal care activities? Is the patient’s dominant upper extremity affected?Does patient live with caregivers? Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: •Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Document height, weight, and body mass index (BMI). Is weight loss indicated for health promotion?
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Does the patient use assistive aids for ambulation? If so, what type and is it being used correctly? Is shoulder pain associated with any assistive device??
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess static and dynamic balance. Use Berg Balance Scale, if indicated by mobility deficits
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Cardiorespiratory function and endurance:  Assess whether ability to use upper extremities, as indicated by occupation or sport, is limited by cardiorespiratory function
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Upper extremity peripheral pulses and general vascular status in patients with CT should be normal and equal bilaterallySensation to light touch should be intact in the C4-T2  dermatomes bilaterally. Conduct cervical scan to rule out radiculopathyExpect active guarding of involved arm in forward flexion, adduction and internal rotation during functional activities; perform work station assessment as appropriate
relevant tests and measures.functional mobility: Assess ability to perform bed mobility and transfersAlthough accessory motion of the shoulder joint may be reduced after prolonged restricted movement, pain may prevent this assessment. Assess for capsular tightness, scapular mobility, or a catching sensation on overhead shoulder abduction and forward flexion (which may be suggestive of loose bodies in the subacromial space)
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess upper extremity strength using manual muscle testing (MMT). Expect pain-restricted  shoulder strength
observation inspection palpation includi: Observation/inspection/palpation:  (including skin assessment): Skin appearance is usually normal, although some redness and warmth may be noticed at the point of shoulder tenderness. Assess for scapular dyskinesia during active shoulder movements
Pain:  Deep, dull ache is usually felt in the anterior and lateral aspect of shoulder(14)
Palpation: Global tenderness about the shoulder, with point tenderness at the greater tuberosity of the humerus
relevant tests and measures.posture: Shoulder may be rounded forward (scapula protracted) with arm adducted and internally rotated to relieve pain. Assess for postural abnormalities such as scoliosis or scapular winging, etc.
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Expect pain-restricted  active ROM in all planes. Passive ROM will likely increase pain (i.e., empty end-feel)  with no capsular pattern detectable. Patients who present after prolonged shoulder immobilization may have shortened, tight, and mildly atrophic extremity muscle groups that restrict ROM. Range of motion should be recorded using goniometric measurement
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Upper extremity deep tendon reflexes should be intactUse of a disability assessment outcomes measure may be necessary to determine the extent of impairment in ADLs(16) -Shoulder Pain and Disability Index (SPADI) -Subjective Shoulder Rating Questionnaire (SSRQ) -Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH) Outcome Measure -For more information about the DASH, see Clinical Review…Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH) ; CINAHL Topic ID Number T903177

cryotherapy precautions: Hypertension  cold can lead to an increase in blood pressure
Avoid aggressive treatment with cold modalities over an acute wound
Avoid placement over superficial nerves for extended periods (> 1 hour)
Cold may be counterproductive if being used to facilitate muscle relaxation and reduce pain in patients who do not tolerate the modality
Over the region of a cardiac pacemaker
Over the pelvis, abdominal and lumbar regions during pregnancy
In an area with infection or bleeding
If a tumor is present in the area
In the area of a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or thrombophlebitis
Over the heart, stellate or cervical ganglia
Ineffective communication skills in a patient (e.g., impaired cognition, language barrier)
Note: Always decrease ultrasound intensity if the patient complains of discomfort
contraindications precautions: Do not use laser with pregnant women
Do not use over the unclosed fontanelles of children
Do not use over cancerous lesions, the cornea, endocrine glands, or hemorrhaging lesions
Do not use LLLT in patients with epilepsy, fever, malignancy, decreased sensation, or infection
Avoid using LLLT over epiphyseal plates in skeletally immature children
Avoid using LLLT over the gonads, sympathetic ganglia, vagus nerve, or mediastinum
Goggles with an appropriate optical density rating should be worn by the patient
other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment in their assessment and treatment decisions

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary presented below is meant to serve as a guide and does not replace orders from a physician or the specific protocols of the treatment clinic

To reduce the risk of partial or complete tears related to therapeutic exercise, gradually introduce and slowly progress shoulder muscle eccentric training. Avoid aggressive tendon stretching in early rehabilitation ›Contraindications/precautions to use of modalities and electrotherapy  (17)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: CT/shoulder pain with impaired function in the affected upper extremity
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Shoulder impingement syndrome Rotator cuff tendinitis or tear Adhesive capsulitis Labral tear Shoulder dislocation/subluxation Biceps tendinitis Cervical radiculopathy
prognosis: Nonoperative management is successful in up to 90% of patients(18)

Authors of a cohort study (n = 420 patients with chronic CT) in Germany found that that 27% of patients had a poor outcome after nonoperative treatment for a minimum of 3 months. Predictors of a poor outcome were(19) –Bilateral CT –Localization of deposit to the anterior portion of the acromion –Medial (subacromial) extension of deposit –High volume of deposit ›Authors of a retrospective cohort study (N = 431 patients with CT) in the Netherlands found that needle aspiration of calcific deposits (NACD) failed at follow-up  of at least 6 months in smokers compared to nonsmokers(32)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines To practitioners that offer ESWT for adjunctive treatment To orthopedic surgeon if pain persists after trials of conservative therapy –Arthroscopy to visualize calcific deposits –UGN technique to promote calcium resorption –Debridement –NACD –Acromioplasty in patients withsevere impingement
other considerations: Authors of a case series (N = 50 consecutive cases) in the United states found that surgical debridement for refractory supraspinatus CT may promote earlier return to unrestricted activity without pain than debridement with concomitant subacromial decompression(20) –The debridement-only  group (n = 25) returned to unrestricted activity by an average of 7 weeks earlier than the debridement plus decompression group (n = 25), i.e., 11 weeks vs. 18 weeks –No significant differences were found for long-term  functional outcomes (using DASH) between the groups

Arthroscopic treatment of CT may increase the risk of supraspinatus tears compared to the contralateral uninvolved shoulder –Based on a study of 62 cases (70 shoulders with arthroscopic treatment) in Germany. Additional subacromial decompression surgery was performed on 44 shoulders. After a mean follow-up  of 6 years, new partial supraspinatus tendon tears were found in 11 of 48 (23%) operated shoulders vs. 3 (6%) of the untreated shoulders(21)
treatment summary: In acute or subacute cases, treatment should focus on alleviating pain and pain-related  shoulder disabilities. The American College of Occupational and Environmental Medicine (ACOEM) practice guidelines recommend ROM exercises and strengthening exercises for shoulder pain, but not general aerobic exercises(27)

Conservative management includes therapeutic modalities for pain, scapulothoracic and glenohumeral ROM exercises, NSAIDs, corticosteroid injections, therapeutic ultrasound (US), ESWT, and shoulder strengthening exercises(1,2,14,30)

Non-thermal  therapeutic USmay also be effective for short-term  pain management and restoration of function, particularly in the resorptive phase of CT –Based on a double-blind  randomized trial in Austria(22) –Participants included 63 individuals (70 shoulders), of whom 54 individuals (61 shoulders) finished the trial –Thirty-two  shoulders in the ultrasound-treatment  group and 29 in the sham-treatment  group  –US treatment parameters were: -frequency: 0.89 MHz -intensity: 2.5 W/cm2 -mode: pulsed 1:4 -duration: 15 minutes -24 total treatments –Significantly reduced calcium deposits and pain were found in the shoulders receiving ultrasound treatment (42% resolved, 23% improved) compared to the sham treatment (8% resolved, 12% improved) at 9-months  follow-up –It should be noted that the above parameters differ from the general recommendations published in a popular reference text are(17) -frequency: 1 or 3 MHz -intensity: 1 to 2 W/cm2 -mode: continuous -duration: 10minutes

UGN studies: –Authors of a quasi-experimental  (no control group) trial of 106 patients with CT in Italy found that one treatment of UGN followed by one month of shoulder rehabilitation (vaguely described in article) and multidisciplinary pain management (also not well described) was considered effective for reducing pain and improving function(23) –Authors of a randomized controlled trial(RCT; N = 48 patients with CT) in the Netherlands compared US-guided corticosteroid injection in the subacromial bursa versus UGN treatments. At 1-year  follow-up,  clinical and radiographic results were significantly better in the UGN group(39) –Authors of a double-blinded  RCT (n = 132 patients with CT) in France compared the amount of calcific resorption afterUGN plus steroid injection with that after UGN plus saline (placebo) injection. Steroid injection improved pain more than saline at 6 weeks post-  procedure, as well as function at 3 months post-procedure.However,  the rate of resorption was not significantly different between groups at 1-year  follow-up(40)

ESWT studies: –Authors of a single-blind  RCT(n = 90 patients with CT) in Italy found at 6-months  follow-up  that positioning the shoulder in hyperextension and internal rotation during radial ESWT (3 sessions) was more effective for removal of calcific deposits than treatment in the neutral position(24) –Authors of a 2013 systematic review found that ESWT dissolves calcifications in the shoulder, improves shoulder function, and decreases pain in patients with calcific tendinitis(28) –Authors of a 2014 systematic review of 20 RCTs (n = 1,745 patients with CT) found that ESWT significantly decreased pain and improved function compared to placebo treatment(33) –Authors of a prospective trial (n = 54 patients with CT) in South Korea found that UGN was more effective than ESWT for improving shoulder function and decreasing pain at 1-year  follow-up  and for reducing the mean size of calcium deposits at a mean of 23 months follow-up(34) –Authors ofan RCT (N = 42 patients with CT) in Italy compared ESWT sessions followed by kinesio taping (KT) once a week for 3 weeks versus ESWT without KT applied. Both groups showed significant improvements in V AS, DASH, and SSRQ outcome measures at 4-weeks  and 12-weeks  follow-up,  but the ESWT+KT group improved more at 1-week follow-up(39) –Authors of a 2017 systematic review and meta-analysis  (7 studies) concluded that UGN treatment improves subjective outcomes slightly more than ESWT(41) .
